title: Site-wide clickjacking at IE11
vulnerability_information:
Hey team,

I have discovered that the protection you use for clickjacking preventing is a CSP with `frame-ancestors` directive. But IE11 doesn't support this directive so you customers using this browser can be attacked. The market share of IE11 is about 2.5% now and it's higher than, for example, Firefox' one.

###Steps to reproduce
1) Sign into the NR app with admin/owner using IE11
2) Navigate to `https://xn--1xa.su/pocs/nr_clickjacking.php?acc=2336392` replacing the `acc` parameter value with your own account ID
3) Make sure the sensitive part of a page (containing the REST API key) is successfully embed into iframe

I could show another scenarios with almost every sensitive action at your app, because this vulnerability is (almost?) site-wide.

###Video-PoC
{F509228}

## Impact

Attacker can attack the customers which use IE11 and force them to perform almost any sensitive NR app actions.

activities.message:
###Mitigation
You should add the `X-Frame-Options` response header into all your server responses to protect the IE11 users too.
@skavans I'm just now trying to reproduce this. I'll let you know what I find.

@skavans I'm having trouble reproducing this. Nothing happens when I open the PoC site and the API key frame is open in a different tab. I will try to find the bit about X-Frame-Options not protecting our IE users from the backend, but maybe you have instructions or can show me the clickjacking code so that I can try to reproduce it locally.

Hi @jmcaleer,

I thought that the PoC doesn't work for you because of different screen resolution and tested it at 3 other than my (at Windows 10 and 7), but everything works as it should.

Please try to open the following URL at IE11: https://xn--1xa.su/nr_cj.html

It shows that the page can be embed into iframe.
{F511339}

As for my initial PoC, there I show how the specific webpage part can be embed into malicious site to forge user and force him to perform some sensitive actions.

> Nothing happens when I open the PoC site and the API key frame is open in a different tab
The API keys tab even shouldn't be open, you just need to be signed into the NR at this browser (and then you can close every NR tab).

So the attack scenario is that the user visits malicious site somehow, and this site embeds NR page into the iframe and forge user to interact with it (to click the buttons to perform sensitive actions or to copy and paste the API key, as I showed you at PoC video). Attacker can even make this iframe transparent so user thinks he clicks at some malicious site control, but the click is actually is performed against some NR app control.

Please let me know if you still need some help with reproducing the issue. 

The PoC's source code is very simple:
```html
<html>
	<iframe width="100%" height="100%" src="https://rpm.newrelic.com/accounts/2336392/integrations?page=api_keys"></iframe>
</html>
```
You just need to serve it at some domain, it doesn't work if you just open the HTML-file from your computer.
@skavans I'm so sorry, I didn't see that you had replied! Going to reproduce this now.

Hey guys,

I've performed an investigation and I can't reproduce behavior you describe, if all PoC steps are executed correctly. Below is more detailed video explaining possible causes of your reproducing difficulties.

P.S.: Please do not pay attention to that I use the browserstack instead of real IE browser. The security settings are default and I've tested this at 2 different real Windows 10 with the latest IE, the behavior remains strongly the same. 

P.P.S.: Please make sure you serve the PoC under some internet-domain if you use your own PoC. It doesn't work if you save the PoC into HTML-file and open it from disk, I think it is because fo some IE protection from interaction between **intra**net and **inter**net.

Please let me know if you need more assistance.
{F516164}

@jmcaleer,

First, apologies for too much time it takes to reproduce this (not impactful so much) issue.

I think you are right and the causes are here, because I don't see the errors like yours when reproducing this:
> I get the following errors in the console when I go to the github.io page:

I've tried just now to serve the PoC at github.io and it continues to work well ¯ \ _ (ツ) _ / ¯

I've googled about the errors you stumbled upon, and discovered that some people are having difficulties with "framing+https" cases after some browser update (or certificates update), stumbling upon the errors exactly the same as yours.
Below is my IE's `about` window screenshot.
{F516321}

Is it possible that there are some *extra* IE security features turned on by your security policy?
Is it possible that you use custom root certificate that can be the cause of these errors?

If you have time, you can also try to use a fresh Windows virtual machine and try to reproduce the issue there.

I'll google it a little further and will notify you if I have some extra thoughts.

Please read this also https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19653940/https-security-is-compromised
It'll maybe help.

After discussing with my coworkers, we realized a few things that make us believe this is only informational:
(1) We only do Legacy support for IE and adding X-Frame-Options for a browser we don't actually support doesn't sound like the best use of our developers' time. It's actually less than 1% of traffic and we don't plan on continuing that support.
(2) On top of that, this relies on social engineering. The person has to go to this malicious link, copy and paste the key in the malicious site in order for the attacker to actually obtain it, otherwise it just appears on the user's screen and the attacker never sees it.
(3) The api key iframe does not have a state change. If you look at our policy page, we specifically call out clickjacking that does not have state changing requests as out-of-scope. We have this because clickjacking for non-state changing requests can usually only be seen by the user and require some sort of social engineering in order to obtain the response information.

I'm sorry for wasting your time trying to reproduce this only to realize it doesn't fit our policy scope.  Please let me know if there's anything I misunderstand that makes this more severe.

Hey @jmcaleer,

1) You are right, this really works at IE11 only, I even specified this in report title to let you know about it as soon as possible.
2-3) But you are not right here because I specified at my initial report that
>I could show another scenarios with almost every sensitive action at your app, because this vulnerability is (almost?) site-wide.

For instance, below is an example of disabling the Webhook integrations (it is state changing) through this vulnerability.
{F516618}

The frame is semi-transparent at the video, but it can be fully invisible of course.

This PoC hosted here: https://xn--1xa.su/pocs/nr_clickjacking.php?acc=2336392
Just make sure first, that the webhook integrations are enabled.
I'm going to work with my coworker to try to reproduce the webhook one, because maybe it's just a user error ¯\\\_(ツ)_/¯ We'll see. Let me get back to you.

Sorry, discussed with a teammate: We're going to decide if the first point of IE not being supported makes us want to keep this as Informative. If so, we'll update the New Relic official documentation AND the policy page. If not, I'll work with my coworker to try to reproduce the webhook one.
Ok, I’ll be patiently waiting :)

I was rereviewing your videos and all the data, and it looks like you have a custom level for security in IE. One of my coworkers turned off all the security protections and my PoC worked. When resetting the security protections to the default and restarting IE, the PoC was still able to fire. I'm still inclined to believe this is an issue with the IE (whether it's the specific configuration or some kind of issue with IE not actually resetting to default even though it says it does?). I'm still confirming about whether we care about IE, but just in case someone comes back and says we do care, I want to follow up on reproducing. 

@skavans Would you be able to start a new VM with internet explorer at the default security level and confirm if it still works?

@skavans We were able to get this to fire, only by turning the privacy settings all the way off (which is why restoring default security settings didn't fix it before). If you'll check your privacy settings and confirm whether they're on or off.

Hey @jmcaleer,

Please accept my apologies for the late reply. 

I've just re-watched my first video and have noticed that the `Internet` zone settings are really set to `Custom`, not `Default`. 
{F517794}

And after resetting them to default I've reproduced the behavior you describe, so I confirm the PoC doesn't work when the settings are set to `Default` level.
But. It is really strange that my PoC was working well at all the devices I've tested it at. The strangest thing is that there was one device, IE didn't start at whenever. Maybe the `Default` settings level isn't default actually? 

So please give me a few more time to check the settings set at them. I'll let you know after doing this investigation.

@skavans I sent you a bunch of messages yesterday as I was trying to figure out the issue, so sorry if this got lost in the haystack: there's a privacy tab in the IE settings, if this is turned all the way off, or New Relic is added as a trusted site, the payload is able to fire.
@jmcaleer I've definitely not added NR as a trusted site or switch off the Privacy... So I'll check the other devices settings further.

{F517833}

Checked this at other device. It seems that Privacy is switched on and all the other settings are Default. Can you please describe what the parameter differs at your case? Maybe some advanced SSL/TLS acceptance options? I think the error you (and I about an hour before) stumbled upon appears rather because some SSL/TLS policy differs, than because of custom privacy settings.

> And after resetting them to default I've reproduced the behavior you describe, so I confirm the PoC doesn't work when the settings are set to Default level.

This test was performed at browserstack's IE, the test from the video above was performed at real win10. I'll try to compare their settings to maybe understand what is differ.

I'm even unable to reproduce this for one more time 🤦‍♂️
>And after resetting them to default I've reproduced the behavior you describe, so I confirm the PoC doesn't work when the settings are set to Default level.

The PoC now works well after resetting the security level to `Default` at this browserstack's IE11 versions:
11.540.15063.0 (update version 11.0.45)
11.785.16299.0 (update version 11.0.95)
11.15.16299.0 (update version 11.0.47)

I'll try to find the VM win10 image, reproduce the issue there and give you a link to download it if success.

@jmcaleer I've spent a lot of time too to help you with reproducing this issue. So please spend a few more minutes on this.

First, I don't understand what you're talking about saying
> ... you should report that to them as being different than the norm or potentially a flaw in the version
> ... IE is only supported for Windows

Maybe there was some misunderstanding?

1) I've said to you that the issue is reproducible at least at 2 different real Windows 10 computers with default settings.
2) When you said that you have difficulties, I've tried many IE11 versions at BrowserStack (it operates with Windows10 VMs, not something non-Windows) to find the possible causes of the behavior you described.
3) Just a single of tens of my tries was resulted in the same behavior as yours and I tried to investigate this to understand the causes.

Below is the 
>detailed explanation of how it is the default, and what exact configuration is necessary in order to reproduce it

###Steps to reproduce
1) Download the "Microsoft approved VM" from https://developer.microsoft.com/ru-ru/windows/downloads/virtual-machines (~20Gb). I think we can consider the VM image from Microsoft site to be enough approved and default, can't we?
2) Import the downloaded VM image into your virtualization software. I've used the VirtualBox.
3) Start the VM and open the IE, do not touch any settings at all.
4) Sign into the NR app using the following account:
`skavans+71@wearehackerone.com:P@ssw0rd!!`
5) Navigate to https://xn--1xa.su/pocs/nr_clickjacking.php?acc=2385914
6) Make sure there are `Disable webhooks` button embed into a frame, so the clickjacking is possible.

{F518014}

If you are still having difficulties with reproducing this following the steps above, or doubt in the "defaultness" of this config, then feel free to leave the report closed as an `Informational`.

Thanks!

Hey @skavans I was able to reproduce with a fresh Win10 VM using default configurations from [here](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/tools/vms/) (the one you linked was a developer edition, these are the "approved" ones I was talking about). I'm currently going through and finding the iframes in order to give our developers a more concrete fix than just "all the iframes".

I'm sorry this was so frustrating.

Hey @jmcaleer,

I’m glad to hear you’ve been successful with reproducing this. 
> I'm currently going through and finding the iframes in order to give our developers a more concrete fix than just "all the iframes".

I’m sorry, I don’t understand this a little. Do you mean you don’t want to forbid all the iframe ancestors? It seems you can use `X-Frame-Options: allow-from https://rpm.newrelic.com` but for the single ancestor only, and no wildcards. If you really need to support more than just one ancestor for IE, it seems that the only way to support them is to use some parameters like:
```
https://rpm.newrelic.com/?frame_ancestor_id=1
->
X-Frame-Options: allow-from https://1stdomain.newrelic.com

https://rpm.newrelic.com/?frame_ancestor_id=2
->
X-Frame-Options: allow-from https://2nddomain.newrelic.com
```
So when you legally embed a page into another domain, you will add this extra parameter to every frame source URL, and the webserver should check this parameter value and get a corresponding *origin* from some table to provide the necessary `X-Frame-Options: allow-from <origin>` header.

I'm not worried about the domains that are being allowed in the X-Frame-Options. I'm talking about finding all the URL requests that have `Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors <origin>` and adding `X-Frame-Options`. You've mentioned two here: webhooks and API keys. I would like to find them all because this is across all of RPM, as you mentioned.

Got it. It seems that you can find through the apps, not the URLs themself. For example all the account settings’, apm’s, browser’s, plugin’s URLs are vulnerable. But for instance Synthetics’ URLs are not. Insights are protected too.
We finally made it! Thank you for working with me @skavans. Always appreciate that you're so willing to explain and do thorough investigation.

Hey guys,

█████
Guys, I’ve seen you paid some report the day before yesterday, so it would be MUCH appreciated if you can pay me today. I’m building a house and the money is pretty over :)) Thanks!

The likelihood for this vulnerability is extremely low due to the how few of our customers use IE (it would require an attacker to target one of the few customers we have using it) and social engineering in order to exploit. Thus making the severity a low.
Thank you guys. Take a look at #629113 too please.

Hey @skavans,

We believe this is finally resolved! Thank you for finding this and I look forward to working with you again soon.
Can we disclose this?
